creator: jessh@ptc.com
text:
JSP pages previously had been able to use jsp:param ala:
  <jsp:param name="foo" value="<%=bar%>"/>
without regard for whether the variable 'bar' is non-null.

Due to the use of URLEncoder.encode() on the value attribute in the generated 
code, such JSP pages now error out with NullPointerExceptions.  This may or may 
not be more correct, but is certainly harmful to existing pages!

creator: jessh@ptc.com
text:
A resolution on this issue is quite important.  If this is not a bug per se, it 
would seem highly desirable to allow null's in this situation anyway as 
previous versions of Tomcat and other major servlet engines (e.g. JRun, 
iPlanet) do null throw exceptions upon passing null values to jsp:param.

Also, is use of URLEncoder.encode() really the best tactic considering that it 
does not handle non-ASCII characters?  Should the characters first be UTF-8 
encoded and then URL encoded to handle this?

See bug 10671 which lists more issues I found with Tomcat 4.x's approach to 
jsp:param since filing this bug.
creator: jessh@ptc.com
jessh@ptc.com
text:
There is talk of calling 4.1.10 a final release, but yet this apparent spec 
violation has not been fixed?!?
